chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess suspected balanitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Assess for clinical features which may suggest specific underlying causes of balanitis.

  • Ask about:
    • Symptoms and their onset and duration, including dysuria, pain, itch, bleeding, splitting, dyspareunia, sexual dysfunction, urethral discharge or exudate.
    • Additional symptoms such as joint problems or eye involvement (may suggest Reiter's syndrome or Chlamydia infection).
    • Hygiene practices, for example, how often nappies are changed in children, or how often the penis is cleaned. 
    • Exposure to potential irritants or allergens, such as soaps, bubble bath, detergents, or creams; latex condoms or lubricants.
    • Exposure to new drugs (may suggest a drug eruption) and any over-the-counter treatments tried.
    • Trauma, for example from 'foreskin fiddling' in children; or during sexual intercourse or vigorous cleaning in young men and adults.
    • A history of other skin conditions, such as eczema or psoriasis.
    • Sexual history and risk taking, any partner conditions (including bacterial vaginosis or vaginal candidal infection), and exposure to sexually transmitted infections (STIs), if appropriate.
    • Symptoms or a history of diabetes mellitus, HIV, or other cause of immunosuppression, which may predispose to severe or persistent infection.
  • Examine the penile skin for clinical features of balanitis or its complications.
  • Examine the genital area and extra-genital skin for specific clinical features suggesting an underlying cause. In adult men, examine the genital area for signs of:
    • Pre-malignant or malignant disease, and manage appropriately if suspected clinically. See the CKS topic on Urological cancers - recognition and referral for more information.
  • Do not routinely perform a sub-preputial swab to confirm the diagnosis, but consider swabbing for Candida sp. and bacterial culture and sensitivity if symptoms are severe (suggesting a secondary infection).
  • Consider arranging an STI screen if there is a high risk or suspected infection (for example ulceration, blisters, or inguinal lymphadenopathy), depending on clinical judgement, and manage appropriately.
  • Arrange a blood test for HbA1c to assess for underlying diabetes mellitus and HIV (if appropriate), if balanitis is severe (especially if candidal balanitis is present). See the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1, Diabetes - type 2, and HIV infection and AIDS for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment are based on expert opinion in the 2013 European guideline for the management of balanoposthitis [Edwards, 2014], expert opinion in the Royal College of General Practitioners and British Association of Sexual Health and HIV (RCGP/BASHH) publication Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [Lazaro, 2013], and expert opinion in a review article on benign male genital skin conditions [Shim, 2016] and penile inflammatory skin disorders [Morris, 2017].

  • The European guideline states a sub-preputial swab should be taken for candida and bacterial culture and sensitivity in most cases to exclude an infective cause or superinfection of a skin lesion or dermatosis [Edwards, 2014].
    • The recommendation to arrange swabbing if balanitis is severe is based on the fact that most cases are secondary to non-specific dermatitis with or without candidal or bacterial infection, which usually responds to empirical treatment. This is pragmatic advice, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice, and is based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendation on considering and assessing for underlying immunosuppression such as diabetes mellitus and HIV if there is severe or persistent balanitis (or confirmed candidal infection) is based on expert opinion in the European guideline [Edwards, 2014] and in a review article [Morris, 2017].
